ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: We learned a lot about the history of vaccines and how complicated vaccines and the policy surrounding them is.
A background in the history of vaccination in the United States.
A comprehensive understanding of US vaccination history.
We learned about the history of anti-vaccination movements, debates regarding medical authority, eradication campaigns, etc

Discussing vaccination topics from a variety of perspectives
Tracing the patterns of vaccination through various historical periods
Writing about current and past vaccination events

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: 
- The two short paper assignments were really interesting to get us thinking about topics that interested us in the history (and present) of vaccines.  
-  The course didn't assume any real outside knowledge which was fantastic! I appreciate the time we took to understand different kinds of vaccines and governmental agencies that deal with vaccines. 

Weaknesses:
- The vast majority of our readings centered on white, wealthy experiences of antivaccinationism and I think it was a huge omission to not talk more expansively about how issues of class and race impact the history of vaccines. We talked quite a lot about gender and motherhood, but we only briefly/tangentially explored how forms of oppression impact vaccine access and information.
Strengths: cool assignments, Professor Schwartz is great (super available, knowledgeable, really enjoyed hearing about current events at the beginning of class). No weaknesses.

Strengths - interesting readings and class discussions
Weaknesses - some discussions felt repetitive, class felt less seminar-style and more lecture at times.
Professor Schwartz is an absolute joy to work with!

Strengths: reading load was manageable, clear instructions for writing assignments, good instructor feedback
Weaknesses: I didn't feel very connected to any of my classmates, and I ended the class without knowing the majority of their names
It was a great course! The length of the final paper felt a bit long but it did allow us to go in-depth with primary sources, which was a great experience.
discussion was too structured sometimes; i wish students had an opportunity to bring in their own questions more often

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! Super fascinating history to learn
Definitely. Especially coming out of the COVID pandemic, I think that this course has a lot of insight to add with regards to a lot of health things we don't often think about.
Yes, it will give you a very thorough understanding of vaccination history.

I would absolutely recommend this course to anyone who is interested in this topic! The workload for the class is pretty reasonable, with weekly reading responses, two midterm papers, and a final paper. Professor Schwartz is very understanding, and does his best to make this class a low-stress environment.
Yes. The course was interesting, not stressful, and I learned a lot.
Definitely! Super relevant and well-organized, with a great professor
